item.title: Terminate batches quickly in VSCode
item.description: Don’t you ever get tired of being asked “Are you sure you want to terminate the batch?” every time you try to terminate a batch in VSCode? I know I do.

item.title: Using Teams Toolkit with NVS
item.description: NVS is great when you need to switch between different versions of Node.js within a VSCode project. But Teams Toolkit needs a default version of Node.js installed – before you start your project. Here is how I fix it.

item.title: Associate Node.js version with your SPFx solutions
item.description: If you use a node version manager like nvm or nvs, wouldn’t you like to automatically load the right version of Node.js when you open an SPFx solution in VSCode? I know I do. Because I am lazy.

item.title: Wait... where did all the content go?!
item.description: You may have noticed that most of my content is missing. Don’t worry, it is coming back… Eventually.

item.title: From PowerPoint to Demos Easily With Desktops
item.description:
Introduction

If you’ve ever tried to give a PowerPoint presentation and switch to your desktop to do a demo, you may have noticed that PowerPoint tends to fight with you to stay in slide show mode.

item.title: Summarized GitHub cheat sheet for PnP contributions
item.description: This is an interactive post that you can customize to get a personalized list of commands you’ll need when contributing to a PnP repository on GitHub.

item.title: Launching Edge with different profiles using shortcuts
item.description: Find out how you create create shortcuts that will launch your Edge browser with a different profile. Bonus: find out how to configure your Stream Deck buttons to launch Edge, Teams, and conference calls using different browsers.

item.title: My Demo Checklist for PnP Calls
item.description: I’m not a great presenter. I have been working in IT for over thirty years, during which time I have done many technical demos… and failed many of them.

item.title: Getting rid of JSON validation errors on comments
item.description: Introduction If you’re an SPFx developer who uses Visual Studio Code, you may have noticed that the JSON files that the Yeoman generator creates contain comments to help you understand how to configure your manifest. The only problem is: JSON files aren’t supposed to have comments.

item.title: Adding custom Edge profile images
item.description: Edge Chromium lets you use different browsing profiles, but did you know that you could have custom profile images for each one? Here’ show.

item.title: Working with rules in Microsoft Lists
item.description: Microsoft Lists will soon make it easy to create rules to react to changes in your lists. Find out what I’ve learned so far.

item.title: Adding support for theme variants in SPFx web parts
item.description: Like chameleons, SPFx web parts can change colors to adapt to changing environments and blend in. Find out how to build good-looking web parts on any theme.

item.title: Getting to know Microsoft Lists
item.description:
Introduction

As Microsoft Lists starts rolling out to Microsoft 365, I find that more and more people seem to get confused about Microsoft Lists vs SharePoint, or complaining about how they’ll have to “learn a new product … again!”.

item.title: Solving the “Failed to execute ‘removeChild’ on ‘Node'” error on modern SharePoint pages
item.description: If you’re getting errors in modern SharePoint pages when trying to open a link in a new tab, read this.

item.title: SPFx Projects, SCSS, Pseudo-classes, and Stylelint
item.description: In this post, I’ll show you how you can use SCSS pseudo-classes in your SPFx projects and configure stylelint so that it doesn’t give you any warnings.

item.title: Display the solution version in your web part
item.description: Find out how you can automatically synchronize your NodeJS package version with your web part solution version and display it in a web part’s property pane.

item.title: Generate Word documents from a template using Power Automate
item.description: With some Word template know-how and Power Automate, you can dynamically generate documents in your business processes. Find out how!

item.title: Accessing Your On-Premises Data Using the On-Premises Data Gateway
item.description: The on-premises data gateway allows your cloud-based Power Platform services to access your on-premises data, such as databases, file shares, and SharePoint data. Find out how it works and how to u…

item.title: Find Your SharePoint Online Tenant ID without tools or code
item.description: Sometimes you just need to find your SharePoint Online tenant ID and you don’t have access to the Azure Admin center.

item.title: Simplify workflows with desired paths
item.description: Find out how designing Power Automate workflows and the Ohio State University campus have in common.

item.title: Leveling the playing field with accessibility
item.description: Find out how the Xbox Adaptive Controller gives everyone the opportunity to be anyone they want to be online

item.title: SPFx Compatibility Matrix
item.description: Here is a handy compatibility matrix telling you which version of SharePoint and SPFx work together.

item.title: Redirect your users to SharePoint Online with Smart 404
item.description: In today’s post, we unearth an old SharePoint feature from 2009 and create a more contemporary version of it to help redirect users from your old on-premises SharePoint to SharePoint online.

item.title: Working as multiple Office 365 users using user profiles in Edge Chromium
item.description: Using Edge Chromium, you can open multiple browser windows as multiple Office 365 users. Here’s how to do it.

item.title: The Sharing is Caring Initiative
item.description: Making your first contribution to the SharePoint PnP community can be scary!

item.title: Ultimate Developer Tool List for SPFx
item.description: I asked the SharePoint Developer Community what development tools they use on their workstations to develop SPFx solutions. They came through!

item.title: Fixing base64 SVG icons in SPFx
item.description: According to Microsoft, you should be able to use a base64-encoded SVG image for your web part icon, but it hasn’t worked in a while. Here is how to fix it.

item.description: In today’s post in the web part layout series, we discuss the compact layout.

item.title: Popular PnP repositories and how to get started contributing
item.description: Here is a list of the most common SharePoint Developer community repositories and information to get started with each one.

item.description: In today’s post, we’ll set up a SharePoint list and walk you through how to implement the flow, step-by-step.

item.title: Using Flow to synchronize an iCal feed to a SharePoint event list — Part I
item.description: Today, we’ll explain how to use Flow to import events daily from an iCal feed into a SharePoint list.

item.title: August 2019 Updates to SharePoint pages and news authoring — updates for busy people
item.description: My goal is to take major SharePoint/Office 365 announcements, videos, and other relevant pieces of information which may require too much time for busy people to read and watch, and to boil it down to the essential.

item.title: August 2019 Updates to SharePoint pages and news authoring — updates for busy people
item.description: If you’ve ever used Visual Studio’s Web Deploy feature to deploy using a file share, you may have experienced issues where some files cannot be overwritten because they are in use. You may not already know this: ASP.NET Core has a built-in mechanism to take applications offline and display a message. This article describes how you can use Visual Studio’s Web Deploy feature to automatically take your web application offline while you deploy a new version, and restore it back online when deployment is complete using (pretty much) all out-of-the-box features of Visual Studio and ASP.NET Core.

item.title: Create a Link to a Delve Profile
item.description: Sometimes, you just want to create a link to someone’s Delve profile in SharePoint Online.

item.title: Interactive Post: My GitHub cheat sheet for PnP contributions
item.description: This article focuses on the GitHub commands. If you need help with your first contribution, David Warner II has kindly volunteered to help anyone with their first PnP contribution. He’s a true main on the topic.

item.description: Today’s post is a companion to the Designing SharePoint web part page.

item.title: SharePoint Framework Design Series: Layout Patterns — Part III
item.description: In today’s post, we’ll continue our discussion about the web part layout patterns and discuss the carousel layout.

item.title: SharePoint Migration: Mind the URL Length
item.description: This article discusses the current limitation with URL lengths in SharePoint. It discusses how this limitation manifests itself, and how it can impact you during your SharePoint migration.

item.title: Would you like to create low-fidelity SharePoint wireframes in PowerPoint?
item.description: I’m not a designer or a user experience specialist, but I’ll take the time to do paper napkin drawings, whiteboard drawings, and any other available tools to help work through how my sites are going to be structured and laid out.

item.description: Today’s post is a companion to the Designing SharePoint web part page.

item.description: Today’s post continues on my previous post. It discusses various aspects of property panes that you may find useful.

item.description: This post will explain some of the tips and tricks to use when buying new software that will help you make an educated decision.

item.title: SharePoint Framework Design Series: Web Part Titles and Descriptions
item.description: Anyone who has worked with me on a SharePoint project knows that I firmly believe that a good custom web part must be indistinguishable from the out-of-the-box SharePoint web parts. They need to look and behave like they were written by whichever awesome team at Microsoft is responsible for writing those things.

item.title: How to tell what version of the SPFx Yeoman generator is installed
item.description: Sometimes you just need to figure out what version of the SPFx Yeoman generator is installed on someone’s machine.

item.description: In this post, I’ll show you how to count how many items were returned by SharePoint and how to test if any items were found.

item.description: Anyone who has worked with me on a SharePoint project knows that I firmly believe that a good custom web part must be indistinguishable from the out-of-the-box SharePoint web parts. They need to look and behave like they were written by whichever awesome team at Microsoft is responsible for writing those things.

item.description: In this post, I’ll show you how to count how many items were returned by SharePoint and how to test if any items were found.

item.title: Using the SharePoint GetItems action in Flow
item.description: This article explains how to use the SharePoint connector and the GetItems action to retrieve items from a SharePoint list.

item.title: Disabling Telemetry network traffic on SPFx workbench
item.description: When testing a SharePoint web part on the SPFx workbench, analyzing network traffic using your web browser’s developer tools can get pretty overwhelming; there are so many telemetry calls every few seconds that it becomes impossible to figure out what calls are real API calls, and which ones are telemetry calls.

item.title: Sorting SharePoint List Items Using a Custom Sort
item.description: Sometimes, you need to create a view in a SharePoint list where the items are sorted using a custom sort order. For example, if you had a list of items that needs to be sorted by Rating where the possible choices are High, Medium, and Low, your list items would appear in the following order: High, Low, and Medium because SharePoint will want to sort your Rating values alphabetically.

item.title: MORE UPDATES: Inject Custom CSS on SharePoint Modern Pages using SPFx Application Extensions
item.description: A while ago, I wrote an SPFx Application Customizer that allows you to insert custom CSS on your SharePoint modern pages and posted about it. The solution is now a sample in the SharePoint SharePoi…

item.title: Setting the default timezone for SharePoint Online
item.description: Every once in a while, I write a blog post as a note to myself about something that I couldn’t find easily with the hope that next time I (or someone else in need) look for it, it’ll be easy to find. This is the case with this one.

item.title: Why I ♥ the Office 365 Dev Community
item.description: This blog post explains why I think the Office 365 Dev Community is awesome and why you should consider becoming part of it.

item.title: The Mysterious Case of the Checked-Out spcommon[1].png
item.description: When migrating from SharePoint on-premises to SharePoint Online/Office 365, you may find that some users have a checked-out file called spcommon[1].png. If you ask users about it, they’ll have no idea what you’re talking about.

item.title: Converting SPFx Web Part from JavaScript to React
item.description: This article is written as if you’re following along and converting the application yourself. Feel free to skip to the end to get the code and compare Eric’s JavaScript-only SPFx web part with my React version of the same web part.

item.description: This article will describe some of the techniques and approaches I used to reverse engineer the out-of-the-box File Picker to create my own.

item.description: This article is a compilation of the best “best practices” articles I could find. I have included the list of articles at the end.

item.title: Multi-Cursor Editing in Visual Studio Code
item.description: This article will demonstrate how to use multi-cursor editing. I don’t think it is particularly earth-shattering, but I do hope that someone else will learn ways to save some keystrokes.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: 3 Ways We Find Content
item.description: If you’ve ever tried to Google something when you don’t have the right keywords, you know how hard it is to find information.

item.title: The Reason I Consult: The Inner Voice of a 40-Something-Year Old with Autism
item.description: Being autistic does not mean being condemned to never achieve anything in life. It comes with its own set of challenges, neither better nor worse than any person — neuro-typical or not.

item.description: This article will give you pro tips to guarantee your migration from SharePoint to Office 365 will fail.

item.description: In software projects, we have a tendency to repeat the same mistakes over and over again.

item.description: I recently published the list of developer tools that I use as a SharePoint Framework developer. The list was inspired from Scott Hanselman’s own list — he deserves all the credit for the idea.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: The Logical Dimension
item.description: In this article, we’ll discuss the logical dimension of IA.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: The Logical Dimension
item.description: In the last article, we looked at the logical IA. While the physical IA caters to your authors, the logical IA should cater to your readers. But there is one more dimension to consider: the metadata dimension.

item.title: Open Source Contributors are People Too!
item.description: Microsoft is changing from the company everyone (but me) loves to hate, and it is becoming cool. Well, cooler.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: Data, Information, Knowledge
item.description: In this article, I’ll discuss how to avoid the “One size fits all” approach for IA, and how it should constantly evolve.

item.description: In this article, we’ll discuss how to create news that will make your employees pay attention to.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: 3 Dimensions of IA
item.description: In my previous post on Information Architecture (IA), I explained how using your organization’s Org Chart leads to bad IA. Unfortunately, creating an IA that caters to every user in your organization, then trying to fit it all in a single navigation structure would be difficult to achieve.

item.title: Information Architecture in SharePoint: Data, Information, Knowledge
item.description: This is the first in a series of articles discussing various aspects of Information Architecture within SharePoint.

item.title: Dynamic default properties in SPFx web parts
item.description: SharePoint client-side web parts (SPFx) allow you to define custom properties that your users can use to customize your web parts

item.title: Getting around CORS issues in SPFx with SPHttpClient
item.description: This article will explain what CORS is, and how to avoid issues with CORS when making HTTP requests to an external resource.

item.title: Dynamically Assign Multiple CSS Class Names in SPFx — The Easy Way
item.description: If you write SPFx web parts or extensions using React, you may have had to assign more than one or more CSS classes to the same element.

item.title: Change default project folder in Visual Studio 2017 to a OneDrive folder
item.description: This article will show you how you too can install and configure this command line interface.

item.title: UPDATE: Inject Custom CSS on SharePoint Modern Pages using SPFx Application Extensions
item.description: A while ago, I wrote an article describing how you can inject a custom CSS stylesheet on SharePoint modern pages using an SPFx application extension. The code sample is now part of the SharePoint SP-Dev-Fx-Extensions repository on GitHub. Since the article, I have been getting tons of e-mails asking all sorts of questions about the solution. Since SPFx 1.6 was released, I took the opportunity to upgrade the solution to the latest and greatest version of the toolset. You can find the latest code on GitHub, or download the latest SharePoint package. In this post, I’ll (hopefully) answer some questions about how to use it.

item.title: Upgrade your SPFx solution to SharePoint Framework Package v1.5
item.description: This article explain a (mostly) pain-free to upgrade your SPFx solution. Waldek explains this process in details, but this is a summary of how to do it.

item.title: Creating a calendar feed web part – Part II
item.description: In this article, we’ll: create a web part solution, add a mock service to return test events, and we’ll display a simple list of events

item.title: Changing your command prompt to display node module and Git information like the SharePoint Conference presenters
item.description: This article will show you how you too can install and configure this command line interface.

item.title: Creating a calendar feed web part – Part I
item.description: So, I thought: why not try re-creating the out-of-the-box SharePoint events web part, but instead of reading events from a SharePoint list (or group calendar), it would read from WordPress?

item.title: Inject Custom CSS on SharePoint Modern Pages using SPFx Extensions
item.description: If you need to customize the look and feel of modern pages, you can use custom tenant branding, custom site designs, and modern site themes without incurring the wrath of the SharePoint gods.

item.title: Displaying site information security classification on every page using a custom SPFx extensions — Part I
item.description: That’s what I hope to do with this series of blog articles: demonstrate easy ways to introduce some level of governance using new enabling technologies — like SPFx web parts, extensions, and site scripts.

item.title: Displaying site information security classification on every page using a custom SPFx extensions — Part II
item.description: In part 1 of this article, I introduced the concept for an SPFx extension that adds a header to every page, showing the classification information for a site. We’ll actually do the coding in this article!

item.title: Displaying site information security classification on every page using a custom SPFx extensions — Part III
item.description: In this article, we’ll discuss how we use property bags to store the security classification.

item.title: Displaying site information security classification on every page using a custom SPFx extensions — Part IV
item.description: In this part, we will finally get to add code to our extension that reads the property bag of the current site and displays the appropriate site classification label.

item.title: Displaying site information security classification on every page using a custom SPFx extensions — Part V
item.description: In this part, we will clean up a few things, package and deploy the extension.

item.title: Automatically deploy SPFx extension to multiple sites using PowerShell
item.description: In this article, I’ll share a PowerShell script I use to deploy to many sites at once.

item.title: SPFx, Semantic versioning, and CHANGELOG.md
item.description: This article is a great example of that mentality. I’m really standing on the shoulder of giants and combining a few links and re-using someone else’s code (with credit, of course) to document what my approach to versioning SPFx packages is, with the hope that it helps someone else.

item.title: Creating SPFx web part property panes with an Apply button
item.description: When you create an SPFx web part, the default Property Pane automatically submits changes to the web part. There is no “Apply” button. But sometimes you don’t want changes to the property pane fields to automatically apply. All you have to do is to add this method in your web part class…

item.title: Getting to know SharePoint Hub sites
item.description: Unless you’re a SharePoint geek like me, you may not have been eagerly waiting for this new feature announced at Ignite 2017 in Orlando. Hub sites are a special site template that allows you to logically group team sites and communication sites under another site, with a shared navigation, theme, and logo.

item.title: Saving files from a SharePoint document library to a local folder using CSOM
item.description: I was trying to write a little app to programmatically download files from a SharePoint instance on Office 365 to a local folder on my hard-drive/network file share — something I’ve probably done a thousand times

item.title: Getting Windows 10 Build 10122 to install on a Surface Pro 3
View an Article Page in Edit Mode using Query String Parameters
item.description: You may never need this tip, but I recently ran into an issue where my article page’s Edit Page button stopped working in SharePoint 2013 (probably something I messed up with the master page… I’ll fix it later). I Googled and Binged everywhere, but couldn’t find how to switch an article page to edit mode.

item.title: Uploading High Resolution User Profile Pictures in Office 365
item.description: In Office 365, you can upload profile pictures for each user’s contact card. The contact card will appear in Outlook, SharePoint, Lync, Word, Excel, PowerPoint… well, in any Office product that displays contact cards

item.title: Uploading High Resolution User Profile Pictures to Office 365 Using PowerShell
item.description: Although you can use the web-based GUI to update profile pictures on Office 365, sometimes you need to upload many pictures at once.

item.title: Uploading User Profile Pictures using the Web-Based GUI
item.description: In my previous article, I discuss best practices on how to choose high resolution photos to use in user profile pictures for Office 365.

item.title: Play SketchFlow/WPF Animation Programmatically
item.description: Microsoft Expression Blend makes it easy launch animations. It is easy to launch animations with a few clicks… But sometimes, you need to launch animations from within your code – for example, to launch an animation after performing calculations. This article will show you how to play an animation from within your code.

item.title: Customizing New, Edit, and Display List Forms using InfoPath
item.description: A new feature in SharePoint 2010 is that you can customize the form that is displayed when you create a new list item by using InfoPath. That means that you can leverage the extensive capabilities of InfoPath without having to write a single line of code – and that’s a good thing, if you’re as lazy as I am and want to avoid resorting to custom code.

item.title: About
item.description:
I’m Hugo Bernier

The world’s laziest developer

I started working with SharePoint back when it was codenamed Tahoe — before it actually became SharePoint 2001. I have been working with it ever since.

item.title: Contact me
item.description: I am passionate about technology, and I love to share my experiences with others. If you have any questions, comments, or feedback, please do not hesitate to contact me. I will do my best to respond to you as soon as possible.

item.title: Creative
Privacy
item.description:
Privacy Policy

Last updated: June 27, 2022

This Privacy Policy describes Our policies and procedures on the collection, use and disclosure of Your information when You use the Service and tells You about Your privacy rights and how the law protects You.

item.title: Public speaking
item.description: I am lucky to be able to travel all over the world to speak on topics that I feel passionate about.
